byline.original: By NOEL PERRIN;  Noel Perrin's most recent book is ''Second Person Rural."

results.lead_paragraph: PRIZE STORIES 1982 The O. Henry Awards. Edited and Introduced by William Abrahams. 321 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95. THE RANDOM REVIEW 1982 Edited by Gary Fisketjon and Jonathan Galassi. 317 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $14.50. Ballantine Books. Paper, $3.95 IN one of Isak Dinesen's stories, a Danish nobleman sits thinking about roses. A rose isn't a rose, he reflects - at least, not in art. Depending on where and when the painter lived, it inevitably becomes a Chinese or a Dutch, a rococco or an Empire rose - and something he personally can date within 20 years and place within 500 miles. He then reflects how curious it is that he can do this, since the artist had not set out to express time or place; he had just aimed to paint a flower.

results.snippet: One day about a year from now, if all goes as planned, the space shuttle Challenger, sister ship to Columbia, will lift off from Cape Canaveral to begin America's seventh shuttle flight.   As it rises on its multiple tails of fire, a slight,...

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: One day about a year from now, if all goes as planned, the space shuttle Challenger, sister ship to Columbia, will lift off from Cape Canaveral to begin America's seventh shuttle flight. As it rises on its multiple tails of fire, a slight, 5-foot-5-inch, 115-pound figure will be seated just behind the pilot and co-pilot, acting as flight engineer, helping to monitor the glowing cockpit lights and gauges that tell whether all is well. That will be history. For the flight engineer will be Sally K. Ride, the first American woman to fly in space. She laughed with obvious appreciation the other day when someone suggested that she is about to become the subject of a trivia question forever. But in a more serious moment, reflecting on the fact that she has now become a premier role model for millions of girls and young women, she says there is no doubt in her mind about what has cleared the way for her to take that seat in Challenger's cockpit next April. It is the women's movement.

results.snippet: WASHINGTON TWO mountain-climbers are trapped on an icy ledge 27,000 feet above sea level. They have lost most of their life-saving equipment in a snowslide and they are miles away from potential rescue. It looks as if they will perish before the...
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON TWO mountain-climbers are trapped on an icy ledge 27,000 feet above sea level. They have lost most of their life-saving equipment in a snowslide and they are miles away from potential rescue. It looks as if they will perish before the sun sets. So what do they do? At the top of his voice, one of them yells, ''Helllp!'', and they both laugh helplessly. One of the most emboldening aspects of Patrick Meyers's ''K2'' at the Arena Stage is its knowledge of its own absurdity. What are those two men - one a district attorney, the other a nuclear physicist - doing so near to the top of the world? In the course of a dramatic cliffhanger, we learn that even they aren't sure of their reasons: they know they have climbed the mountain because they are there.

headline.main: ART IN PUBLIC PLACES STIRS WIDENING DEBATE

results.snippet: ''The fastest-growing industry in the United States,'' a Government official joked recently, ''is public art.'' The statement isn't so far-fetched. Public art blossomed in the 19th century, with its rage for battle monuments and statues of heroes...
results.lead_paragraph: ''The fastest-growing industry in the United States,'' a Government official joked recently, ''is public art.'' The statement isn't so far-fetched. Public art blossomed in the 19th century, with its rage for battle monuments and statues of heroes on horseback. Another surge came in the 1930's and 40's, when - as Depression aid - the Treasury Department and the Works Progress Administration gave to hundreds of artists commissions for public buildings. But there has probably never been such a proliferation of art for public sites as in the last two decades. Spurred by grants from the Federal Government, local ordinances that give a percentage of public building costs to art, commissions from image-building corporations, and the belief by business and civic leaders that art will enhance the ''quality of life'' in their communities, an invasion of monumental proportions has spread throughout the country. And in many areas, including New York, it is causing intense debate. Selected for the most part by art professionals, but not always loved by those who have to live with them, the new public icons adorn buildings, plazas, parks, malls, meadows, subway stations, electronic billboards -even rivers and city dumps. Their raison d'etre is the notion that art benefits the community, but unlike the old-style commemorative works, they tend to be abstract, and to celebrate the creative process of a particular artist, rather than a person or event.

headline.main: DATA SHOW MILLIONAIRE CLUB IN SENATE IS STABLE

results.snippet: In 1981, members of the Senate once again were better off than their legislative contemporaries in the House, financial disclosure reports have shown.   As the Senate worked on the budget for the fiscal year 1983, a preliminary review Thursday of...
results.lead_paragraph: In 1981, members of the Senate once again were better off than their legislative contemporaries in the House, financial disclosure reports have shown. As the Senate worked on the budget for the fiscal year 1983, a preliminary review Thursday of disclosure reports from 95 of the Senate's 100 members indicated that the chamber's club of millionaires, as many as 41 in past years, had probably lost no members. As in the House, members took advantage of new rules removing limits on the amount they could collect in speaking fees. The House doubled its limit to about $18,000, but the Senate lifted its $25,000 ceiling altogether.

results.snippet: 1974) who, while building a major independent oil company and amassing one of the world's largest fortunes, welcomed public attention as paterfamilias, superpatriot and health crank and secretly sired two illegitimate families. Harry Hurt, a Texas...
results.lead_paragraph: 1974) who, while building a major independent oil company and amassing one of the world's largest fortunes, welcomed public attention as paterfamilias, superpatriot and health crank and secretly sired two illegitimate families. Harry Hurt, a Texas Monthly editor, concludes the story with the recent disastrous attempt by two of Hunt's sons to corner the world's silver supply. PHILOSOPHER OR DOG? by Machado de Assis. (Avon/Bard, $3.95.) In this sequel to his classic, ''Epitaph of a Small Winner'' (Avon/Bard, $2.25), the Brazilian novelist Machado de Assis (1839-1908) chronicled the fortunes of a provincial schoolteacher who, after inheriting a fortune on condition that he take care of his benefactor's dog, moves into a Rio de Janeiro mansion and a world of new experiences, among them insanity. The introduction by the translator, Clotilde Wilson, will help North American readers appreciate the irony and other forms of literary caviar that were Machado's specialty.

results.snippet: Serenaded, satirized and soaked during two rainswept days of graduation activities, 3,009 students received degrees today at the 281st commencement of Yale University.   ''You will never forget being part of the most massive baptism in the history...

byline.original: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Serenaded, satirized and soaked during two rainswept days of graduation activities, 3,009 students received degrees today at the 281st commencement of Yale University. ''You will never forget being part of the most massive baptism in the history of the United States,'' the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of New York, said in his benediction, His listeners included 1,235 seniors, 1,774 students in graduate and professional schools and 11 recipients of honorary degrees, among them Philip C. Habib, James Earl Jones and Benny Goodman. Opposes Prayer Amendment In his baccalaureate Sunday, Yale's president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, assailed President Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment to allow voluntary prayers in public schools as part of ''a politicizing of the schools for radical goals, cloaked in the rhetoric of morality and equity,'' ''I do not believe it is the Government's obligation, and it should not become it, to encourage through the Constitution in the public schools organized religious expression,'' Mr. Giamatti said, Mr. Giamatti's attack on ''certain moral politicians'' - he did not identify any - came at the end of an academic year that began with his attack on the Moral Majority for propounding ''dangerous, malicious nonsense.'' Those remarks, intended for a speech to incoming freshmen, were released in September while Mr. Giamatti was in the hospital.
